channel.title: NPR All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Ari Shapiro, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.

item.title: What happened at last night's American Music Awards
item.description: Musical icons, legends and ingenues graced Las Vegas Monday for the 2025 American Music Awards. The AMAs are the largest fan-voted music awards show, featuring performances and some viral moments.

item.title: NPR's president and CEO talks about lawsuit over executive orders
item.description: NPR and several public radio stations are suing the Trump White House over an executive order that purportedly bars the use of Congressionally appropriated funds for NPR and PBS.

item.title: States look to pull back incentives on electric vehicles
item.description: Even some states led by Democrats look to pull back incentives on electric vehicles as budgets tighten and as the Trump administration turns back on Biden-era EV promises.

item.title: Comedian Mike Birbiglia shares one of the lessons he learned from his parents
item.description: On Wild Card, well-known guests answer questions we often don't discuss. Comedian Mike Birbiglia talks about his relationship with his parents as he figured out how to tackle serious ideas with a kid.

item.title: King Charles says Canada is facing unprecedented challenges in speech
item.description: King Charles warns Canada 'faces a critical moment' in an official address to open parliament in Ottawa - delivering a message aimed at reasserting the nation's sovereignty amid Trump's taunts.

item.title: A Peruvian farmer in the Andes is challenging a European energy giant
item.description: High in the Andes, a Peruvian farmer challenges a European energy giant as a German court nears a landmark climate ruling.

item.title: Have federal cuts affected our food safety?
item.description: Remember that big recall of deli meat last year? Food safety experts say its more likely to happen more often after job cuts to FDA, USDA and CDC.

item.title: Can Pope Leo revitalize Catholicism in Chicago?
item.description: Now that the world's most famous Catholic is an American from Chicago, some hope Pope Leo XIV will help bring new energy to a church that's been on the steady decline there.

item.title: Why pro-Russian media is focusing on a viral video of French President Macron
item.description: A video showing French President Emmanuel Macron's wife appearing to shove him in the face has gone viral. Macron has said the two were just sharing a moment of closeness.

item.title: In a county that backed Trump, people dependent on Medicaid are conflicted about cuts
item.description: In an Arizona county that voted for Trump 2-to-1, many people rely on Medicaid, would hate to lose it, and are persuaded that there is fraud that can be cut from the program.
